data.title: The Best New York Knicks Centers of All Time
data.meta_description: Over 500 sports fans have voted on the 60+ athletes on Best New York Knicks Centers of All Time. Current Top 3: Patrick Ewing, Willis Reed, Amar'e Stoudemire ...
data.text:
Ranked By

2.7K votes

511 voters

2 reranks

Voting Rules

Vote up the players who had the most success for the New York Knicks

Latest additions: Isaiah Hartenstein

Most divisive: Enes Kanter Freedom

Over 500 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The Best New York Knicks Centers of All Time

Big fan of New York basketball? Then check out this list of New York Knicks centers. It includes almost every center from throughout New York Knicks history, including current centers and past ones. Featuring some of the greatest NBA centers of all time, the best Knicks Cs include Patrick Ewing, Willis Reed, Bob McAdoo, and Charles Oakley.

In the 2021-22 NBA season, the current New York Knicks starting Cs and backup Cs are Mitchell Robinson, Nerlens Noel, and Taj Gibson.

Who are the best centers in New York Knicks history? Vote below and help decide the greatest Knicks centers of all time!

Birthplace : Kingston, Jamaica

Nationality : United States of America

Team : New York Knicks, Orlando Magic, Seattle Supersonics

Position : Center

New York Knicks: 1985–2000

As the first overall pick in the 1985 NBA Draft, Patrick Ewing quickly became a dominant force on the New York Knicks and is often considered one of the best centers of all time. Known for his exceptional shot-blocking ability and offensive prowess, Ewing was a perennial All-Star who led the Knicks to numerous playoff appearances during his tenure with the team. With various accolades under his belt, including being named the NBA Rookie of the Year in 1986, All-NBA First Team in 1990, and capturing two Olympic gold medals, Ewing's impact on the franchise is revered by fans and analysts alike.

Birthplace : Hico, Louisiana

Nationality : United States of America

Team : New York Knicks

Position : Power forward, Center

New York Knicks: 1964–1974

Serving as a powerful example of perseverance, Willis Reed's heroic return during Game 7 of the 1970 NBA Finals remains one of the most iconic moments in basketball history. Drafted by the Knicks in 1964, Reed developed a well-rounded game as an adept scorer and tenacious defender, earning him the accolade of NBA MVP in 1970. A seven-time All-Star, Reed led the Knicks to two NBA championships and became the first player ever to win the Finals MVP award twice before his eventual induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame.

Birthplace : USA, Florida, Lake Wales

Nationality : United States of America

Team : New York Knicks

Position : Power forward, Center

New York Knicks: 2010–2015

Signed as a free agent in 2010, Amar'e Stoudemire played a pivotal role in revitalizing the Knicks franchise during his time in New York. Known for his explosive athleticism and exceptional pick-and-roll skills, Stoudemire earned an All-NBA Second Team selection in 2011 and was named an All-Star three times with the Knicks. Although injuries ultimately limited his time on the court, Stoudemire's impact during his tenure remains a bright spot in the team's recent history.

Birthplace : Cleveland, Ohio, USA

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward, Center

New York Knicks: 1988–1998

Acquired in a 1988 trade, Charles Oakley quickly established himself as the enforcer and ultimate team player for the Knicks. With his relentless rebounding, tough defense, and blue-collar work ethic, Oakley became a beloved figure among New York fans. A two-time All-NBA Defensive Team selection, Oakley contributed significantly to the team's deep playoff runs in the early 1990s, creating a lasting legacy for years to come.

Birthplace : Greensboro, North Carolina

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward, Center

New York Knicks: 1976–1979

Acquired by the Knicks in a 1976 trade, Bob McAdoo brought dynamic scoring ability to the team, averaging more than 26 points per game during his three seasons in New York. A versatile big man with excellent shooting touch, McAdoo was named an All-Star twice during his tenure with the Knicks and earned two NBA scoring titles before joining the team. While he did not win any championships with New York, McAdoo's impact on the team's offensive identity is still remembered by fans and historians.

Birthplace : Hartford, Connecticut

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Portland Trail Blazers

Position : Power forward, Center

New York Knicks: 1998–2002, 2012–2013

Joining the Knicks in a 1998 trade, Marcus Camby quickly proved himself as an integral part of the team's playoff success. In his four seasons with the Knicks, Camby provided a formidable shot-blocking presence in the paint, earning him a reputation as one of the league's premier defensive players. Although he never won an NBA championship with the Knicks, his contributions played integral roles in the team's deep playoff runs and endeared him to loyal Knicks fans.
